Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Domain-General and Domain-Specific Training to Improve Children's Mathematics

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project, a collaboration between researchers at the University of Maryland and the University of California-Irvine, will test the benefits of training activities for improving the mathematical achievement of kindergartners from low-income backgrounds using newly-developed tablet computer games. The gap in mathematical proficiency between children from different socioeconomic backgrounds is present before children enter elementary school, and it progressively widens over the course of schooling. Importantly, these early differences in mathematical knowledge predict the rate of growth in mathematics learning and achievement as late as high school. The investigators will examine improvements in children's numerical knowledge as well as improvements in working memory. The project is funded by the EHR Core Research program, which supports fundamental research that advances the research literature on STEM learning.

The project examines how interventions targeted towards improving children's numerical knowledge (domain-specific skills) or their working memory (domain-general skills) might promote their mathematical achievement. The interventions will involve playing game-like activities on tablet computers over the course of several sessions. The main focus will be on children from low-income backgrounds who are most at risk for poor scholastic achievement due to their deficits in early mathematical skills and working memory capacity. Specifically, the project will 1) examine improvements in low-income children's conceptual and procedural numerical knowledge (domain specific skills) as well as improvements in working memory and executive control (domain general skills) by targeting either numerical knowledge or working memory in isolation, 2) examine the additive effects of a combined domain-specific and domain-general approach, 3) examine the longevity of any effects by follow-up testing participants several months after training completion, and 4) examine individual differences in the benefits of the training activities to determine whether preexisting abilities mediate and moderate training outcomes, and to examine whether specific interventions are more beneficial for a certain subpopulation of children than others. The findings should shed light on the underlying mechanisms of the development of mathematical skills, and advance the field's understanding of how different cognitive systems are differentially affected by specific interventions. This knowledge has implications for the development and implementation of evidence-based interventions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to examine whether individual tablet-based interventions targeting either numerical knowledge (domain-specific skills) or working memory (domain-general skills) might improve children?s numerical knowledge and/or working memory skills as assessed with several measures that are different from the training games. We also explored whether there are additive benefits of combining interventions for numerical knowledge and working memory, and examined the longevity of any effects from the training games. To address our goals, we conducted three separate studies involving over 400 kindergarten-aged children from diverse backgrounds and found benefits from playing both, the domain-specific and the domain-general games, as well as when the games were played in combination. The observed effects were most pronounced in numerical knowledge, although we also found improvements in working memory. Some of the effects remained present several weeks after training completion, however, we also observed individual differences in that the interventions were not equally effective for all children. We are currently conducting analyses combining the data across all three studies to get a better understanding of potential underlying factors that might drive training efficacy. Overall, the intellectual merit of the project includes two dissertations, as well as numerous conference presentations and a published paper in Developmental Science, and additional papers that will result from this work in the months to come. Furthermore, our data provide tentative evidence that targeted tablet-based games can lead to lasting transfer effects in a broad range of kindergarten-aged children. Finally, the development of our games and assessments resulted in two new grants from the NewSchools Venture Fund (EF+Math) that will focus on the implementation of equitable game-like assessments and a 5th grade curriculum that will embed working memory games into mathematical practice.

The broader impacts include research and dissemination opportunities for a large number of undergraduate students involved in the project, many of which consisted of first-generation and/or underrepresented minorities. Furthermore, we argue that playing game-like interventions targeting numerical knowledge and/or working memory could serve as useful supplements to the kindergarten curriculum in that they can be easily implemented by teachers in a classroom, e.g. as part of circle time.
